p.content: This section covers intransitive, copular, transitive, ditransitive and passive sentences in their basic surface word order (i.e. not changed by focus, topic, interrogative, or negation constructions). As noted in section
, the typology of
is

case.caseText: SVO, so the basic word order is the subject, then any auxiliary elements, then the verb phrase which consists of the verb in initial position and any complements following it.
SOV, so the basic word order is the subject, then the verb phrase which consists of the verb in final position with any complements preceding it, then any auxiliary elements.
VSO, so the basic word order is the verb in initial position, then the subject, then any complements.
VOS, so the basic word order is the verb phrase which consists of the verb in initial position and any complements following it, then any auxiliary elements, then the subject.
OVS, so the basic word order is the verb phrase which consists of the verb in final position with any complements preceding it, then any auxiliary elements, then the subject.
OSV, so the basic word order is any verbal complements first, then the subject, then the verb in final position.

text.content: The order with any auxiliaries present will be discussed in section

p.content: Before discussing each of the sentence types in turn, general issues of inflection and agreement features, pro-drop, and auxiliaries will be covered.
Verbs and auxiliaries usually carry inflection features, such as tense, aspect, and/or mood. In most cases, these features are added by affixes, but may also be part of irregular verb forms.
The following inflection features are marked on verbs and/or auxiliaries in

Verbs and auxiliaries may also carry agreement features that force agreement with the subject, and sometimes also with the direct object. Most of these features are added by affixes or pronominal clitics which may attach to the verb. Animacy of a subject or object is most likely a property of the semantics of the individual verb itself.
The following agreement features are marked on verbs and/or auxiliaries in
Some languages are pro-drop languages which allow a subject and/or object to be missing. For example, in Spanish the normal way to say "I buy a book" is
p.langData: Compro un libro
p.content: rather than with the overt subject pronoun included:
p.langData: Yo compro un libro
p.content: . This is not allowed in English, except for imperatives. (The missing subject of infinitives in embedded complements will be covered in section

Some languages are not really pro-drop languages, but at least some of the pronouns are clitics which can attach to the verb. When this happens, there is no pronoun or nominal phrase in subject position, so the sentence appears the same as in a true pro-drop language.
In

case.caseText: pro-drop is not allowed. The subject must be overt except in imperatives.
pro-drop is not allowed. The subject must be overt even in imperatives.
pro-drop of the subject is allowed in any type of sentence.
the subject may look like it is missing due to pronominal clitics attaching to the verb, but it is not a true pro-drop language.
not
also

text.content: Examples showing a missing subject in imperatives include:
Examples that look like pro-drop include:

p.content: Some languages have auxiliary elements that are separate words, and some can have more than one auxiliary element before the main verb. Examples for English transitive single-clause sentences include:
p.langData: The boy will hit the ball
The boy might have hit the ball
p.content: and
p.langData: The boy might have been hitting the ball

case.caseText: does not have any
has some

p.content: auxiliaries which are written as separate words.

case.caseText: optional
required
only one is possible
more than one may occur

text.content: After an auxiliary, the normal VSO order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is Aux V S O.
may change so the subject appears directly after the auxiliary and before the verb. The order in these clauses is Aux S V O.

text.content: Before an auxiliary, the normal OSV order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is O S V Aux.
may change so the subject appears directly after the verb and before the auxiliary. The order in these clauses is O V S Aux.

p.content: Examples of auxiliaries in
are:
Examples of sentences including these auxiliaries are:
In some languages verbal negation is an auxiliary element, while in others it is simply a verbal affix. English has both the negative auxiliary
p.langData: not
p.content: , which is a separate word that must always follow another auxiliary, and the contraction form
p.langData: -n't
p.content: , which is written as a suffix on the auxiliary. Examples of English negative transitive single-clause sentences include:
p.langData: The boy did not hit the ball
The boy won't hit the ball
p.content: and
p.langData: The boy might not have hit the ball

case.caseText: has one or more
has one or more
has one or more
has one or more
does not have any
does not have any
does not have any

p.content: negative auxiliaries which are written as separate words,

case.caseText: and that is the only type of verbal negation in the language. There is no negative verbal affix nor negative auxiliary affix.
and there is also a negative auxiliary affix, but no negative verbal affix.
and there is also a negative verbal affix, but no negative auxiliary affix.
and there is also a negative auxiliary affix and a negative verbal affix.
but there is a negative affix which goes on the auxiliary and that is the only type of verbal negation in the language. There is no negative verbal affix.
but there is a negative affix which goes on the auxiliary and a negative verbal affix as well.
nor any negative affix which goes on an auxiliary. The only way to express verbal negation is by one or more negative verbal affixes.
may
may not

text.content: be the only auxiliary in the phrase;

case.caseText: no other
the presence of another

p.content: Examples of the negative auxiliaries in
include:
Examples of the negative affix(es) attached to an auxiliary word in
include:
Examples of the negative verbal affixes attached to a verb in
include:
See section
for examples of these negative elements used in sentences and further discussion of the negation constructions in
The nonfinite word
p.langData: to
p.content: used in English embedded clauses also acts as an auxiliary in that it fills the same position and can occur before other auxiliaries. For example,
p.langData: The boy would like to have hit the ball

case.caseText: does not have any
has some

p.content: nonfinite auxiliary-type markers which are written as separate words.

case.caseText: optional
required

text.content: After a nonfinite auxiliary, the normal VSO order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is Aux V S O.
may change so the subject appears directly after the auxiliary and before the verb. The order in these clauses is Aux S V O.

text.content: Before a nonfinite auxiliary, the normal OSV order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is O S V Aux.
may change so the subject appears directly after the verb and before the auxiliary. The order in these clauses is O V S Aux.

p.content: Examples of auxiliaries of this type in
are:
Examples of nonfinite clauses including these nonfinite auxiliaries are:
Some languages have other words that act like auxiliaries, such as motion auxiliaries or loan markers, which are written
the verb and share the same subject and complements.

case.caseText: does not have any
has some

p.content: auxiliaries of this type which are written as separate words.

text.content: After one of these auxiliaries, the normal VSO order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is Aux V S O.
may change so the subject appears directly after the auxiliary and before the verb. The order in these clauses is Aux S V O.

text.content: Before one of these auxiliaries, the normal OSV order

case.caseText: is maintained. The order is O S V Aux.
may change so the subject appears directly after the verb and before the auxiliary. The order in these clauses is O V S Aux.

p.content: Examples of these other auxiliaries in
are:
Examples of sentences including these other auxiliaries are:
Simple intransitives do not have any complements after the verb, such as in
p.langData: The girl swims
p.content: . Motion verbs include a location in the form of either a PP or adverb. English examples of motion verbs include
p.langData: The girl ran around the track
My mother went to the store
p.content: and
p.langData: My teacher came here

p.content: Examples of simple intransitive sentences in
include:
examples with motion verbs include:
Copular sentences can have an adjective, PP, or nominal phrase following the copular verb. Some languages do not require a copular verb or auxiliary to be present. English examples include
p.langData: The girl is pretty
She seems nice
The girl is in charge
p.content: and
p.langData: He is the leader

p.content: In
copular sentences,

case.caseText: an overt copular verb is required.
a copular verb is optional, and no auxiliary is required either.
a copular verb is optional, but an auxiliary is required if the copular verb is not present.
there is no copular verb, but an auxiliary is required.
neither an overt copular verb nor an auxiliary is used.
not any copular affix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective either.
a copular prefix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective, however
a copular suffix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective, however
either a copular prefix or suffix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective, however

text.content: , that occurs when there is no copular verb present.

p.content: Examples of copular sentences in
include:
Examples of English transitive single-clause sentences include
p.langData: The batter will hit the ball
My baby wants that toy
p.content: and
p.langData: The dog might have buried his bone

p.content: examples of transitive sentences include:
Ditransitives can have the second object expressed as a PP or as a nominal phrase. Some languages, like English, allow both types via Dative Movement, as in
p.langData: The girl gave the gift to her mother
p.content: and
p.langData: The girl gave her mother the gift

p.content: In
, the second object in a ditransitive

case.caseText: is always a PP.
is always a nominal phrase. The
can be either a PP or a nominal phrase. When both objects are nominal phrases, the
direct object
indirect object

p.content: Examples of ditransitive sentences in
include:

Most languages also have passive sentences, where the Theme or Patient fills the subject position. The Agent may be optionally expressed in some languages, but is not allowed at all in others. If expressed, it may take the form of a PP (as in English with the particular preposition
p.langData: by
p.content: ) or of a nominal phrase, depending on the language. In addition, a particular auxiliary may be required in passives (a form of
p.langData: be
p.content: in English). English examples with and without an agent phrase, including some showing interaction with multiple auxiliaries are:
p.langData: The glass was broken
The glass was broken by the child
The ball might have been hit
p.content: and
p.langData: The ball might have been hit by the boy

case.caseText: does not have any passives.
has passives
may not be expressed.
may be expressed
PP.
nominal phrase.
is not
is

p.content: Examples of passive sentences in
include:
